subject: Law
title: Jurisdiction in International Law
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Jurisdiction in International Law.

hook.text: A US citizen commits a crime in France. Who has jurisdictionâ€”the US, France, or both?

buildup.text: Jurisdiction is the authority of a state to prescribe, enforce, and adjudicate rules within its territory.

discovery.text: Territorial jurisdiction is primary: crimes on your soil, your courts. But nationality and effects also create claims.

twist.text: Universal jurisdiction applies to the worst crimesâ€”genocide, piracy, tortureâ€”any nation can prosecute them.

climax.text: Overlapping claims create conflicts. Extradition treaties help, but nations often disagree on who gets the case.

punchline.text: Every country draws its own lines. International law tries to sort the overlaps.

quiz.question: What is universal jurisdiction?
options: Any nation can prosecute the worst crimes like genocide
